page.title: 19CHURCH,HALL,AND PARK
page.content: A park had existed in Hagley since the time of Edward III,but work began in earnest in 1747.Sanderson Miller built a Gothick ruin,using some medieval stone from the derelict Halesowen Abbey.In 1758,James Stuart built a Grecian temple,known as the{Temple {of Theseus.}At the same time,Thomas Smith built the famous{obelisk. {Hagley Park}is now a haven for the {naturalist.}It contains birds like the woodpecker,treecreeper,nuthatch,finch, warbler,mallard,and moorhen.Mammals to be found include badgers,moles,foxes, squirrels,and rabbits.There is much of geological interest,such as keele and bunker pebble beds,upper mottled sandstone,and Clent Breccia. George Lyttelton replaced the old manor house with the Palladian style Hagley Hall(1756-60),having erected the stable block in 1749.
